issues.title: Owner Registry - Storage Duration (copied over)
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
Copied this over from: https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/173

@cstapl:

Re: 3.15.2

In circumstances that indicate someone is possibly concerned the accessory has been used for unwanted tracking, e.g. upon NFC tap or other owner lookup that indicates the victim has physical access to the accessory (like a button push), we should consider extending the duration of the owner registry storage so that the victim has enough time to engage with the systems required to secure the owner information, e.g. law enforcement and the courts. This is another topic that is important to engage with victim advocacy groups on, for their expertise.

issues.title: Printing Non-SN Unique Identifiers (copied over)
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
Copied this issue over from: https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/172

@cstapl:

3.14 & 3.14.1

Strong concerns that we’re making an allowance for vendors to opt out of printing the unique identifier in an easily accessible location on the physical device. It’s my understanding that those identifiers are a critical part of the physical evidence in law enforcement response to unwanted tracking related calls from victims, and in the prosecution of such cases. Recommend we discuss this issue with victim advocacy groups, and consider requiring all identifiers to be printed on the physical device.

comments.author: npdoty
comments.body:
While there can be a small privacy effect in having a printed serial number, it seems strongly outweighed by the risk of unwanted tracking that couldn't be easily reported. In particular, a rotating identifier electronically accessible via NFC or similar doesn't work for the person who finds an unwanted tracker and smashes it and then still needs the ability to report to law enforcement. While trackers can and should provide disablement instructions, we should anticipate that smashing the device to disable it will be a common action taken for protection.

Because an etched serial number can be scratched out, it seems like there are reasons to include near-field electronic access as well as printed form, and, per dkg, maybe we should recommend that the printed form also be printed internally on the device.

issues.title: Pairing registry data validation (copied over)
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
Copied this over from: https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/28

@siddikaparlak: 

From: [phil@aukilabs.com](mailto:phil@aukilabs.com)
To: authors of draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers, [nils@aukilabs.com](mailto:nils@aukilabs.com)
On: June 7, 2023

The proposal for Registration Data depends on honesty. In section 3.15. Pairing registry, how would the registry data be validated (prepaid SIM, gmail address)? Who would be responsible for managing the personal data with respect to GDPR? While many countries now require formal identification, many do not, leaving the ability to register anonymously available. Recording the IMEI of the owner's device could be valid too. Logging biometric data during registration, possibly with a government-issued identification document could also be considered.

@bledvina:

For the current internet draft the validation of the pairing data would be up to the party doing the accessory pairing.

This topic will likely be revisited as part of the IETF DULT WG, so tagging this with the appropriate label

issues.title: Sound maker requirement
issues.author: siddikaparlak
issues.body: As the tracker sizes getting smaller, it might be a challenge to fit in a sound maker. This issue is to initiate discussion on how to handle this in the accessory protocol.

comments.author: npdoty
comments.body:
Colleagues' blog post on the threats of unwanted tracking for people with disabilities:
https://cdt.org/insights/centering-disability-in-mitigating-harms-of-bluetooth-tracking-technology/

That recommends that we should not only maintain sound requirements, but also look at requirements for haptics/lights so that it's detectable for people that can't easily hear the sound maker.

issues.title: Add NFC requirements section
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
This section of NFC requirements was recently added to the Apple + Google industry standard for unwanted tracking:  https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/blob/main/draft-ledvina-apple-google-unwanted-trackers.md#nfc-requirements-nfc-requirements

A version similar to this should be added to the DULT WG Document #3 

------

NFC Requirements {#NFC-requirements}

Accessories that optionally include NFC (see [Serial number identification](https://github.com/ietf-wg-dult/accessory-protocol/issues/new#serial-number-identification)) MUST support the requirements from this subsecction.

Hardware

These are the hardware requirements for accessories that include NFC:

The accessory MUST use a programmable NFC tag.
NFC tags MUST use the NFC Data Exchange Format (NDEF) as defined by NFC Forum™ in NDEF 1.0 NFCForum‑TS‑NDEF 1.0. An NDEF message is defined as a group of individual NDEF records as defined by NFC Forum™ in NFC Record Type Definition (RTD) RTD 1.0 NFCForum‑TS‑RTD 1.0.
The payload for NFC tags MUST use NDEF URI Record Type Definition as defined by NFC Forum™ in URI Record Type Definition RTD‑URI 1.0 NFCForum‑TS‑RTD URI 1.0.
NFC tag types MUST be type 2 or greater.
The NFC tag SHALL not be scannable when the accessory is still in the packaging.
The payload MUST be scannable when holding an NFC-enabled device near the center of the NFC tag on the accessory. Recommended NFC tag performance guidelines are defined by NFC Forum™ in Tag Performance Requirements Document.
The NFC implemention of the accessory MUST be configured as a NFC tag.
NFC specification documents can be found here {{NFCForum}}.
